posts.description:
Documenting human rights abuses for @witness_change I came across this young man shackled to the floor of Juba Central Prison in South Sudan. His only crime was to have a mental disability. I made a promise to myself that I would do something for the thousands of people like him in countries with insufficient resources to effectively care for people with mental health issues. 
In many countries around the world, the people I spoke to said there was still so much stigma around mental health. I hope you will join me in fighting stigma and creating a better world for people who need mental health support. 
1 in 4 people around the world, experiences a mental disorder or psychosocial disability in their lifetime. 
In some countries, 98% of people with mental illness and intellectually disability receive no treatment

Find out more at 
https://witnesschange.org/condemned/

#worldhealthday #worldhealthday2017 #letstalk #mentalhealth #stopstigma

Photo @Hammond_Robin / @noorimages for @natgeo. Eriah Big Crow at Red Cloud School on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, USA. Eriah wants to be a doctor when she grows up so she can "make people in Pine Ridge better." Eriah is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. While plenty of the kids made it into the digital and magazine edition, Eriah sadly didn’t - just too many great kids to choose from. There are plenty of other amazing children from around the world speaking their minds in the magazine and online version though. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’m sharing them on my account: @Hammond_Robin

Yingzhi is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. @hammond_robin / @noorimages “The First time my experience arrested by police in Kuala Lumpur, I stay in lock up for 2 weeks I was raped by the Inmates. I told the police about my case but the police didn't anything.” Erina, a #trans woman living in #Malaysia, has been arrested twice for cross-dressing. The second time it was not prisoners who abused her, but the authorities. “The religious authority ask me to change my clothes in Front of them. Sharia Law charge rm1000 for trans woman who is waring women's clothes.”
-

“She had made me stay in a chicken hut for three years... her friend told me that its because of the way I behave like a girl that I might rape her kids. It hurt me so much.” Raymond is a #transgender woman from #Uganda. She has faced discrimination for most of her life, but she hadn't felt real fear until the media started 'outing' LGBTQI+ Ugandans: “Things worsened when my face appeared in newspaper on the front page. I started receiving phone calls threatening me from different corners that they are going to kill me and my land lord threw me out that he doesn’t entertain gay people.”

"I don’t want to describe what I felt that evening and how much I was scared, because I don’t want to remember these attacks over and over again, it’s very painfully… Now as I am writing this, I’m hold back the tears because of the shame, because it seems like it's forever, so it will be again and again. Today is #WorldMentalHealthDay
Worldwide, one in four people will live with a mental health problem in his or her lifetime.
Mental and behavioral problems reduce lifespan by as much as 20 years.
In some countries, 98% of people living with mental health problems receive no treatment.
Mental and behavioral problems reduce lifespan by as much as 20 years.
This 14 year old boy who lives with a mental health problem in Northern Uganda has been tied up for six years. Having seen her son heavily sedated before, she refuses to have him admitted to hospital.
To see more follow @Hammond_Robin and @witness_change

Photo by @Hammond_Robin for @natgeo. Was a very nice surprise to find this in the bookstore in Kingston, Jamaica. I was very moved by the story of this family: "We are doing fine here, and we were well received,” says Abed Mohammed Al Khader, 88, patriarch of a family of 16 that fled Syria two years ago, but “we want to go back.” This past February they arrived in Berlin and were given shelter, with 1,500 other refugees, in a large gymnasium near the Olympic stadium. The Syrian and other refugees streaming into Europe since 2015 have roiled its politics and tested its tolerance. But they’re just the latest of many waves of immigrants since World War II that includes Indians in Britain, Algerians in France, Somalis in Sweden, Turks in Germany. See my latest story for National Geographic Magazine to meet some of the immigrants who are reshaping the continent. To see more from this story check out this months National Geographic Magazine
